openai_summarised_points: • The government of the Marshall Islands is the largest employer in the country, employing 30.6% of the workforce, which represents a decrease of 3.4% since 1988.
• The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of the Marshall Islands is primarily derived from payments made by the United States under the terms of the amended Compact of Free Association.
• Direct financial aid from the United States accounts for 60% of the Marshall Islands' national budget, which totals $90 million.
• The principal economic activities in the Marshall Islands include copra production and fisheries, forming the backbone of the local economy.

• Under the Compact of Free Association, Marshallese citizens have the right to travel and work in the United States without requiring visas, a policy that has contributed to a population decline of more than 22% between the years 2000 and 2021.
• The Marshall Islands does not have a central bank, and its official currency is the United States Dollar (USD).
• On 2 April 2025, then-President Donald Trump announced the imposition of a 10% tariff on goods from the Marshall Islands.
• The subsistence economy of the Marshall Islands primarily involves fishing and the cultivation of breadfruit, banana, taro, and pandanus.
• On the outer islands, the production of copra and handicrafts serves as a source of cash income for local inhabitants.
• The modern, service-oriented economy is concentrated in the urban centers of Majuro and Ebeye.
• This modern economy is supported largely by government expenditures and the presence of the U.S. Army installation located at Kwajalein Atoll.
• The airfield at Kwajalein Atoll functions as a secondary national hub for international flights, complementing the primary airport infrastructure.

• The modern economic sector of the Marshall Islands includes wholesale and retail trade, restaurants, banking and insurance services, offshore company registration, construction, repair, professional services, and copra processing.
• Company formation in the Marshall Islands is accessible to both residents and non-residents, with non-residents benefiting from privacy protections and exemption from local taxes.
• Copra cake and copra oil constitute the largest exports of the nation by a significant margin.
• A tuna processing plant in the Marshall Islands employs approximately 300 workers, predominantly women, who earn wages of $1.50 per hour.
• Copra production has been the most important single commercial activity in the Marshall Islands for the past 100 years but currently relies on government subsidies to remain viable.

• These government subsidies for copra production function more as a social policy aimed at reducing migration from outer atolls to the more densely populated areas of Majuro and Ebeye rather than as an economic strategy.
• Marine resources, including fishing, aquaculture, tourism development, and agriculture, are prioritized by the government as key areas for economic development.
• The Marshall Islands generates income by selling fishing rights to other countries.
• In recent years, the Marshall Islands has initiated the registration of ships under its national flag as an additional source of revenue.
• Due to its small size and limited domestic production, the Marshall Islands imports a wide range of goods, including foodstuffs, consumer goods, machinery, and petroleum products.
• In 2019, the Marshall Islands signed a bilateral trade agreement with Taiwan; this agreement was approved in 2023 and is scheduled to take effect at a future date.

• Power authorities, private companies, and entrepreneurs in the Marshall Islands are actively experimenting with coconut oil as an alternative fuel source to diesel for vehicles, power generators, and ships.
• Coconut trees are abundant throughout the tropical islands of the Pacific, providing a readily available raw material for coconut oil production.
• The production of one liter of coconut oil requires the copra derived from approximately 6 to 10 coconuts.

• In February 2018, the government of the Marshall Islands enacted the Sovereign Currency Act of 2018 to create a national digital currency called the Marshallese Sovereign (SOV), aiming to reduce the country's reliance on the U.S. dollar.

• The introduction of the SOV led to a vote of no confidence against President Hilda Heine, who supported the digital currency initiative; this vote occurred in November 2018 but failed due to a parliamentary deadlock.
• The SOV is designed to function as a second legal tender in the Marshall Islands, operating alongside the U.S. dollar rather than replacing it.

• The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that the SOV does not qualify as a central bank digital currency and has expressed concerns regarding potential macroeconomic risks and threats to financial integrity associated with the digital currency.
• Despite opposition from the IMF, the U.S. Treasury Department, and various banking institutions, the Marshallese government has persisted in its efforts to develop and implement the SOV.
• The Marshall Islands is utilizing Algorand’s open-source blockchain technology to maintain the ledger for the SOV digital currency.
• The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of the Marshall Islands at purchasing power parity was estimated at $150 million in 2011.
• The real GDP growth rate of the Marshall Islands was approximately 3% in 2011.
• The GDP per capita at purchasing power parity for the Marshall Islands was estimated at $2,500 in 2011.
• The GDP composition by sector in 2008 was as follows: agriculture accounted for 22%, industry for 18%, and services for 60%.
• The Marshall Islands possess few natural resources, resulting in imports significantly exceeding exports.
• According to the CIA World Factbook, the value of exports from the Marshall Islands in 2013 was approximately $53.7 million.
• Estimated imports for the Marshall Islands in 2013 were about $133.7 million, indicating a substantial trade deficit.
• Key agricultural products of the Marshall Islands include coconuts, tomatoes, melons, taro, breadfruit, various fruits, pigs, and chickens.
• The industrial sector comprises the production of copra, craft items, tuna processing, and tourism-related activities.
• The CIA estimated the GDP of the Marshall Islands in 2016 to be approximately $180 million.
• The real GDP growth rate in 2016 was estimated at 1.7%.
• The GDP per capita in 2016 was estimated to be $3,300.
• The inflation rate for consumer prices in the Marshall Islands was recorded at 5% in 2007.
• In 2008, the labor force distribution by occupation was 48% in agriculture, 12% in industry, and 40% in services.
• The unemployment rate was estimated at 8% in 2011.
• The national budget for fiscal year 2008/2009 estimated revenues at $169.5 million and expenditures at $112.1 million, which included capital expenditures of $19.5 million.
• Key industries in the Marshall Islands include copra production, fishing, tourism, craft items made from shell, wood, and pearls, and an embryonic offshore banking sector.
• Electricity production in 2008 totaled 114 GWh; however, the specific production percentages by fossil fuel, hydro, nuclear, or other sources were not available.
• Electricity consumption was 57 GWh in 1994, with no recorded electricity exports or imports in that year (0 kWh for both).
• Agricultural products consist of coconuts, cacao, taro, breadfruit, various fruits, as well as livestock such as pigs and chickens.
• Export value was approximately $132 million (f.o.b.) in 2008, with main export commodities including fish, coconut oil, and trochus shells.
• The primary export partners for the Marshall Islands are the United States, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand.
• Imports in 2008 were valued at $125 million (f.o.b.), consisting mainly of foodstuffs, machinery and equipment, fuels, beverages, and tobacco.
• Major import partners include the United States, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Guam, and Singapore.
• External debt was estimated at $68 million in 2008.
• The Marshall Islands receives approximately $40 million annually in economic aid from the United States.
• The official currency is the United States dollar (US$), with 1 US dollar equal to 100 cents, and US currency is used for all transactions.
• The fiscal year in the Marshall Islands runs from 1 October to 30 September.

• Data on population below the poverty line, household income or consumption by percentage share for the lowest and highest 10%, labor force size, and industrial production growth rate were not available.
